bibl.title: English translation [from Spanish] of letter from Maria Teresa Rojas to Philip Showalter Hench, March 17, 1945

div1.p: Rojas expresses her admiration to Hench for his persistent efforts to memorialize the site of Camp Lazear. She talks about her visit to Building No. 1. She was surprised to see it intact since a cyclone just had struck the area and caused considerable damage.

div1.head: English translation [from Spanish] of letter from Maria Teresa Rojas to Philip Showalter Hench, March 17, 1945 See Spanish original.
div1.opener:
Dean - please reburn
This is a translation.
17 March 1945
The Esteemed Doctor Hench:
div1.p:
It gave us great pleasure to receive your letter after so long a time with-
out having news of you. We admire the enthusiasm and tenacity with which
you persist in carrying out your plans in memory of Camp Lazear, in spite
of the difficulties and obstacles due to the war, and we do not doubt that
you will be able to accomplish them.

When I received your letter, I went to visit the little house, fearing,
like you, that the hurricane would have caused considerable damage, finding
with surprise that it had not suffered at all, which is really miraculous,
since this cyclone was the strongest or the worst that we have suffered in
many years. The garden of the little place is totally destroyed; even many
of the great trees have fallen and those that remain standing lost all their
limbs. If you were to see it now, you would not recognize it.

We left the house in Vedado and have come to live on the farm. In this
way we can take better care of the house.

If there is anything that we can do for you, do not hesitate to tell us,
since we are very glad to do all we can to carry out your plans.

We congratulate you sincerely on the new member of the family. Begging you
to extend to Mrs. Hench our sincere congratulations and with regards from
my Mother and Senorita Cabrera, receive a friendly greeting from
